trans-unit.source: Network infrastructure considerations for Site Recovery
trans-unit.target: Network infrastructure considerations for Site Recovery

trans-unit.source: The Azure Site Recovery service contributes to a robust business continuity and disaster recovery (BCDR) solution by protecting and recovering your on-premises physical servers and virtual machines with orchestration and automation of replication and failover to Azure, or to a secondary on-premises datacenter.
trans-unit.target: The Azure Site Recovery service contributes to a robust business continuity and disaster recovery (BCDR) solution by protecting and recovering your on-premises physical servers and virtual machines with orchestration and automation of replication and failover to Azure, or to a secondary on-premises datacenter.

trans-unit.source: This article is aimed at the virtualization team responsible for architecting, implementing, and supporting a BCDR solution and infrastructure that includes System Center VMM and Azure Site Recovery.
trans-unit.target: This article is aimed at the virtualization team responsible for architecting, implementing, and supporting a BCDR solution and infrastructure that includes System Center VMM and Azure Site Recovery.

trans-unit.source: Overview
trans-unit.target: Overview

trans-unit.source: The purpose of your BCDR strategy is to keep your business applications running, and to restore failed workloads and services so the organization can quickly resume normal operations.
trans-unit.target: The purpose of your BCDR strategy is to keep your business applications running, and to restore failed workloads and services so the organization can quickly resume normal operations.

trans-unit.source: Developing disaster recovery strategies is challenging, due inherent difficulty of predicting unforeseen events, and the high cost of implementing adequate protection against far-reaching failures.
trans-unit.target: Developing disaster recovery strategies is challenging, due inherent difficulty of predicting unforeseen events, and the high cost of implementing adequate protection against far-reaching failures.

trans-unit.source: Azure Site Recovery helps you implement protection and failover from your primary data center to a secondary data center (or to Azure) by initially copying (replicating) your primary data, and then periodically refreshing the replicas.
trans-unit.target: Azure Site Recovery helps you implement protection and failover from your primary data center to a secondary data center (or to Azure) by initially copying (replicating) your primary data, and then periodically refreshing the replicas.

trans-unit.source: As a crucial part of your BCDR planning you need to define your Recovery Time Objective (RTO) and Recovery Point Objective (RPO) so that can you get your organization data back online as quickly as possible (with a low RTO) and with minimum data loss (low RPO).
trans-unit.target: As a crucial part of your BCDR planning you need to define your Recovery Time Objective (RTO) and Recovery Point Objective (RPO) so that can you get your organization data back online as quickly as possible (with a low RTO) and with minimum data loss (low RPO).

trans-unit.source: The network design in your organization is a potential bottleneck to your RTO and RPO objectives and solid design planning can help avoid this bottleneck.
trans-unit.target: The network design in your organization is a potential bottleneck to your RTO and RPO objectives and solid design planning can help avoid this bottleneck.

trans-unit.source: Connectivity after failover
trans-unit.target: Connectivity after failover

trans-unit.source: Modern applications are almost always dependent on networking to some degree, so physically moving a service from one site to another represents a networking challenge to make sure applications and workloads are reachable after failover.
trans-unit.target: Modern applications are almost always dependent on networking to some degree, so physically moving a service from one site to another represents a networking challenge to make sure applications and workloads are reachable after failover.

trans-unit.source: There are two main solutions to this issue:
trans-unit.target: There are two main solutions to this issue:

trans-unit.source: **Fixed IP addresses**: The first approach is to maintain fixed IP addresses.
trans-unit.target: **Fixed IP addresses**: The first approach is to maintain fixed IP addresses.

trans-unit.source: Despite the services moving and the hosting servers being in different physical locations, applications take the IP address configuration with them to the new location.
trans-unit.target: Despite the services moving and the hosting servers being in different physical locations, applications take the IP address configuration with them to the new location.

trans-unit.source: **Modified IP addresses**: The second approach requires changing the IP address during the transition into the recovered site.
trans-unit.target: **Modified IP addresses**: The second approach requires changing the IP address during the transition into the recovered site.

trans-unit.source: Option 1: Fixed IP addresses
trans-unit.target: Option 1: Fixed IP addresses

trans-unit.source: From a disaster recovery perspective, using fixed IP addresses appears to be the easiest method to implement.
trans-unit.target: From a disaster recovery perspective, using fixed IP addresses appears to be the easiest method to implement.

trans-unit.source: However there are a number of potential challenges which in practice make it the least popular approach.
trans-unit.target: However there are a number of potential challenges which in practice make it the least popular approach.

trans-unit.source: Azure Site Recovery provides the capability to retain the IP addresses in all scenarios.
trans-unit.target: Azure Site Recovery provides the capability to retain the IP addresses in all scenarios.

trans-unit.source: Before you decide to take this approach let's look at the considerations for the main scenarios (stretched subnet and subnet failover).
trans-unit.target: Before you decide to take this approach let's look at the considerations for the main scenarios (stretched subnet and subnet failover).

trans-unit.source: Stretched subnet
trans-unit.target: Stretched subnet

trans-unit.source: In a stretched subnet the subnet is available simultaneously in both the primary and target locations.
trans-unit.target: In a stretched subnet the subnet is available simultaneously in both the primary and target locations.

trans-unit.source: In simple terms this means you can move a server and its IP (Layer 3) configuration to the secondary site, and the network will route traffic to the new location automatically.
trans-unit.target: In simple terms this means you can move a server and its IP (Layer 3) configuration to the secondary site, and the network will route traffic to the new location automatically.

trans-unit.source: This is trivial to deal with from a server perspective but it has a number of challenges:
trans-unit.target: This is trivial to deal with from a server perspective but it has a number of challenges:

trans-unit.source: From a Layer 2 (data link layer) perspective it requires networking equipment that can manage a stretched VLAN, although this type of equipment is now widely available.
trans-unit.target: From a Layer 2 (data link layer) perspective it requires networking equipment that can manage a stretched VLAN, although this type of equipment is now widely available.

trans-unit.source: The second and more difficult problem is that by stretching the VLAN the potential fault domain extends to both sites, essentially becoming a single point of failure.
trans-unit.target: The second and more difficult problem is that by stretching the VLAN the potential fault domain extends to both sites, essentially becoming a single point of failure.

trans-unit.source: Although unlikely it could happen that a broadcast storm starts and cannot be isolated.
trans-unit.target: Although unlikely it could happen that a broadcast storm starts and cannot be isolated.

trans-unit.source: We've seen mixed opinions about this issue, that range from successful implementation to “never”.
trans-unit.target: We've seen mixed opinions about this issue, that range from successful implementation to “never”.

trans-unit.source: A stretched subnet isn't possible if you're failing over to Azure as your DR site.
trans-unit.target: A stretched subnet isn't possible if you're failing over to Azure as your DR site.

trans-unit.source: Subnet Failover
trans-unit.target: Subnet Failover

trans-unit.source: It's possible to implement subnet failover in order to obtain the benefits of a stretched subnet without actually stretching it.
trans-unit.target: It's possible to implement subnet failover in order to obtain the benefits of a stretched subnet without actually stretching it.

trans-unit.source: In this configuration any given subnet is present at Site 1 or Site 2, but never at both sites simultaneously.
trans-unit.target: In this configuration any given subnet is present at Site 1 or Site 2, but never at both sites simultaneously.

trans-unit.source: To maintain the IP address space in the event of a failover, you can programmatically arrange for the router infrastructure to move the subnets from one site to another.
trans-unit.target: To maintain the IP address space in the event of a failover, you can programmatically arrange for the router infrastructure to move the subnets from one site to another.

trans-unit.source: In a failover scenario the subnets move with their associated protected VMs.
trans-unit.target: In a failover scenario the subnets move with their associated protected VMs.

trans-unit.source: The main drawback to this approach is that in the event of a failure you have to move the whole subnet, which might be a reasonable solution, but could affect failover granularity considerations.
trans-unit.target: The main drawback to this approach is that in the event of a failure you have to move the whole subnet, which might be a reasonable solution, but could affect failover granularity considerations.
